descriptors.defaultMessage: Sound Player
Officers sometimes need equipment to complete the tasks they have been assigned. This screen displays available equipment and allows for it to be assigned to crew members.
This button allows for you to change between the officers assigned to teams and officers without current orders.
This list displays the officers on the selected team or any unassigned officers. White officer names have not been assigned any equipment whereas names highlighted in red are carrying items.
Rooms with equipment you are authorized to access are listed here.  Click to select different rooms from a drop down list.

When you select a room the equipment within will be displayed in this area.  The number in parentheses represents how many there are of that item. By clicking on an item you will transfer it to the ready area.

This is the ready area.  Once you have selected all of the equipment you need to assign select the name of the officer from the area on the right and click “Transfer to Officer.”  If you need to return an item to a room click on the item and it will return to the room it came from.
Officer items will be displayed in the equipment field. Pressing the “Remove Inventory” button will transfer all items to the ready area.
This screen shows a map of the bridge. Hover your mouse over or tap on a station to see its description on the right side of the screen.
Transfer Cargo
descriptors.description: The cargo's original location.

descriptors.defaultMessage: Receive Cargo
descriptors.description: The location that receives the cargo.

descriptors.defaultMessage: Find Cargo
Ready Cargo
descriptors.description: A holding area for cargo which is being transferred.

descriptors.defaultMessage: Transfer Cargo
This screen allows you to move cargo between rooms on the ship.
Use this search box to locate where the cargo you need is being stored.
Use these dropdowns to select the deck and room that the cargo is being held on.

The items that are available in that part of the ship will show up here. Click on the inventory that you would like to move. The inventory will move into the ready cargo area. Click again to increase the amount of that cargo being transferred by one.
Use these dropdowns to select the part of the ship you want the cargo sent.

Ready cargo is cargo which is being prepared to move to another place. Before transferring cargo it is recommended to add all the cargo that you want to transfer into the ready cargo area. You can click on items here to remove them from ready cargo.
Click this button to transfer the items in the ready cargo to the area selected in “Receive Cargo.”
Cyphers are used to decode printed messsages. To do that, match the characters on the message with the cypher characters on the screen.
Click to choose a cypher from the available list here.
Here you can see the cypher characters and the Roman character each one represents.
Controls for all of the stations on the bridge and throughout the ship are managed by the computer core. It runs a sophisticated operating system which mostly takes care of itself.

However, like all software, the computer core is not perfectly engineered. It is succeptible to attacks from outside forces. Hackers and viruses can gain access to the system and corupt files which may cause terminals to shut down. Your job is to keep the terminals running properly. If too many terminals shut down, systems on the ship could behave erratically.
This is a list of the number and status of all the terminals on the ship. When terminals go offline, they need to be restarted.
To restart a terminal you must first selected it then click this button. It may take a few seconds for the restart to complete.

Viruses infect the computer core and cause files to become corrupted. You can easily find and remove viruses by clickig this button to scan for them. If a virus is found select the 'Remove Virus' button to remove it.

You can see all of the users with access to the computer core and all of the files that make the computer core run properly here. Toggle between viewing users and files with these buttons. Click on the 'Users' button now.

Both users and files are organized into access levels, level 1 being the highest most privileged level and level 10 being lowest level. By selecting a level you can view all users with that clearance.

All users appear in this table. You should regularly peruse the user list to make sure there aren't any unusual users on the list. Unusual users may be hackers that have infiltrated the system. Hackers can create viruses in the computer systems so you will want to remove hackers before any viruses are created.

Use these buttons to create a new user or remove the currently selected user. When creating a new user, you must specify a username, password, and level. Only give the user the highest necessary level - they don't need more access than is required.
Click on the files button now. Then choose a level to look at some files.

Files usually have generic and descriptive names. Corrupt files will have names that are unintelligible or odd. These corrupt files will shut down terminals. Fortunately there is an immutable backup you can use to restore corrupt files.
Select a file to restore the file individually. If there are too many corrupt files, you may restore all files on that level. This will create a clean-slate state for the entire level.

It may seem like a lot, but this responsibility is important. Without a careful steward, the computer core could shut down entirely. Keep a close eye on users, scan for viruses, restore files, and restart terminals when necessary and, hopefully, everything will run perfectly smooth.
Occasionally Research and Development reports may become available to you. These reports upgrade, improve, and activate newer ship systems.
If the Research and Development report hasn't been compiled, click here to request it.
Due to the state of upgrades and new systems, the steps available will be very specific. Follow them exactly.

Sometimes a system needs a reactivation code to be entered before it can be upgraded. Click the 'Enter Reactivation Code' button, then press the symbols listed in your upgrade report. Once the reactivation code is accepted, the report will be complete.
The ship’s systems are intelligent enough to know when they are damaged, and to understand generally how to repair them. The list of damaged systems appears here. Select a system to see its report
If a damage report hasn't been compiled you may request it by clicking on this button.
When a system is damaged, instructions to troubleshoot and repair the damaged system will appear here. Follow them exactly to avoid further damage.

Occasionally, systems need a reactivation code to be entered before they can be repaired. Click the 'Enter Reactivation Code' button, then press the symbols listed in your damage report. Once the reactivation code is accepted, the system will be repaired.
Available R&D Reports

descriptors.defaultMessage: The {systemName} is a system which creates an envelope of spacetime around your ship. This envelope serves two purposes: 1) increasing momentum by moving the space around you; 2) decreasing time dilation effects of high velocities. In short, it helps your ship to move faster than the speed of light, getting you to your destination in shorter periods of time. Note that you must use your conventional engines in conjunction with the {systemName}. The {systemName} does not provide propulsion to your ship.

This is where you can change the envelope size surrounding your ship. A larger envelope requires more power to maintain, but gives you room for other ships to follow you in your envelope. Make sure you have sufficient power in your system before using a higher envelope size. Click the button below to activate the {systemName}.

There are four emitters that create your envelope, one for each side of your ship. You must ensure that each has sufficient power to operate as you travel at high speeds. As you travel at high speeds, the emitters will become stressed with the continual warping of spacetime around your ship. If they have enough power supplied, the emitters will be able to compensate for the additional stress.

Here you can see the current size of your envelope, along with the current stress levels, represented with color. The circle background color shows the overall stress level, with blue meaning everything is fine and red meaning you are in danger of envelope collapse. Once activated, graphical representations of the individual emitter stress levels will appear, allowing you to keep track of which emitters are doing well and which need more power.
You can also see the overall stress of the emitters here. Make sure this stays low. If the envelope collapses without being deactivated first, it could be very dangerous for you and your crew.
Deactivate
Activate
Sector Power Adjustment

Envelope Stress
descriptors.description: The jump drive warp envelope surrounds the ship to keep it safe from subspace. This is an energy wrapper, not a stationery sender.

descriptors.defaultMessage: During your mission there are different objectives or goals you need to complete.  Objectives appear with a title and description.

When an objective is completed the circle next to it will be filled. When an objective is changed, a line will strike through the title of the objective. Check back often to remember your objectives so you can work toward their completion.
Mission Objectives
Particle Types
descriptors.description: The particle detector detects different particles outside in space. This is a header for a list of the possible particles that can be detected.

descriptors.defaultMessage: The particle detector is an extension to your external sensors. It allows you to focus your sensors at a specific place around your ship to detect different types of particles.
This is the list of all the types of particles you can detect. Click on one to begin detecting particles.

Click anywhere on the grid to detect particles. You can only detect a specific type of particle within a small area at any time, so you may need to click in several areas to see where all the particles are. Be sure to switch between the different types to detect other particles.
The railgun is a point-defense weapon designed to destroy incoming projectiles. This screen is where bolt are loaded into the railgun.
Here you can see the number of bolts loaded. Make sure you don't run out of railgun bolts!
Load Railgun
descriptors.description: This button adds one bolt of ammunition to the railgun.

descriptors.defaultMessage: Loaded Ammunition: {ammo}
descriptors.description: How much ammunition has been loaded into the railgun is displayed here.

descriptors.defaultMessage: Available Ammunition: {availableAmmo}
descriptors.description: How much ammunition is available to be loaded into the railgun is displayed here.

descriptors.defaultMessage: Click this button to load a bolt into the railgun.
The railgun is a point-defense weapon designed to destroy incoming projectiles. You can use it to defend your ship from attackers.
This basic sensors grid shows the location of any incoming projectiles relative to this ship, shown at the center of the grid.

To fire the railgun, click with your mouse on the sensor grid. A red dot will indicate where the railgun bolt will hit. You must fire very close to an incoming projectile for the bolt to hit its target.
Once an incoming projectile has been destroyed, you will see it explode and disappear.
Here you can see the number of bolts loaded. Make sure you don't run out of railgun bolts!

On this screen you will see a list of the officers that are on the ship. You can see their name, age, gender, position, and rank. Understanding this information will help you to know what skills are available to you and who you are responsible for as a bridge officer.
To find officers faster you can sort the crew by clicking on the description above each column.
Use the next or previous button to scroll through multiple pages.
This alert condition is used when the ship is in danger or under attack. All crew members are put on duty at battle stations.
This alert condition is used when the ship is in a dangerous situation, but is safe for the moment. All crew members enter active duty.
This alert condition is used when the ship needs to be ready for a crisis. All off duty personnel are put on stand by status.
This alert condition is used when the station has a minor problem. All crew, except damage control, is on standard duty.
This alert condition is used when the ship is at normal running status. The crew is on standard duty and the ship is in no known danger.
Alert Condition
Tasks List
Task Instructions
Verification In Progress...
Task Completed
Verify Task Completion
Click and hold this button to charge your sector of the {name}.
You can see how much of the sector is charged with this bar.
Once your sector has been charged click the 'Lock Sector' button.
Once all the sectors have been charged, press this button to activate the {name}.
The {name} is a very powerful device which must be charged in every sector of the ship to be used. It cannot be activated until all sectors are charged.
Flight Config
Return to Main
